Posts.Content: You can do this on your own. You will feel rough from a couple of days after each dose for about a week but you will be able to manage. On rare occasions patients might get a temperature when you will need a bit of looking after. I live on my own and only had a friend or family member with me a couple of times cos they were free. You can do this Restory. Use now and the good weeks in between doses to get organised with a haircut, shopping, freezing some food and doing the washing/ironing for your daughter. Do not worry about housework!!! It is a horrible time but it will be over  before you know it.
Posts.Title: on your own with breast cancer chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I use Audible annd BBC iplayer. At least if I am awake I can listen to something interesting. I cannot lay there awake cos I cannot cope with all my thoughts that are mostly negative in the dark. Eventually I will drop off for a few hours and when I wake up I just have to rewind to the last bit I remember!
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Thanks Unicorn. Totally agree about "letting go" and dealing with my inner most fears that catastrophise my illness. I use CBT strategies and write it all down after a meltdown then go through it when I am feeling more positive and reframe my thoughts. Just dont like feeling like that before going to sleep cos then the nightmares come! Would rather dream of unicorns. Sending you strength and a hug.
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: I use Audible annd BBC iplayer. At least if I am awake I can listen to something interesting. I cannot lay there awake cos I cannot cope with all my thoughts that are mostly negative in the dark. Eventually I will drop off for a few hours and when I wake up I just have to rewind to the last bit I remember!
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Thanks Unicorn. Totally agree about "letting go" and dealing with my inner most fears that catastrophise my illness. I use CBT strategies and write it all down after a meltdown then go through it when I am feeling more positive and reframe my thoughts. Just dont like feeling like that before going to sleep cos then the nightmares come! Would rather dream of unicorns. Sending you strength and a hug.
Posts.Title: Not Sleeping

Posts.Content: Aspen although we are all different it seems generally worse for most before treatment types start. Once you know what you are dealing with I think you will probably stop worrying and trying to keep everything "normal". The chemo is bearable but after 3 ECs I know I feel wretched for the first 5 days. I can do stuff but only if absolutely necessary!!  I would make the most of the next 3 days to get everything done for Christmas then you can rest for a few days before enjoying the big day. My friends set up a Whatsapp group for me so I can share news and ask for help. Take everything on offer - nobody minds. I have learned that everybody knows how rough it is and will think you are amazing for going through it. Thinking of you as you start your treatmen Ann :-)
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, chemo about to start

Posts.Content: Congratulations!
Posts.Title: Cancer free

Posts.Content: Hi Anna I take Emend a couple of hours before I go for chemo. Ann
Posts.Title: Daft question: anti-emetics

Posts.Content: Hi Queenfisher My chemo nurse recommended Udderly moisturiser. I find it is really good. I havent started RT yet but needed it for my cracked fingers and toes as a side effect of the T chemo. She said it will be effective for RT too. It doesnt contain aloe vera so might work for you. All the best xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hello everyone Had a meeting with my oncologist this week to talk about my radiotherapy. He needs to tell his patients all about the side effects with percentage chances. He is very knowledgeable but if I wasnt used to him I am sure that I would be very reluctant to proceed! I was concerned when he told me that if it was known before surgery that I would need RT ( all my lymph nodes were removed as most were cancerous) I wouldnt have had an immediate DIEP reconstruction. He said that there is a chance that my foob could fail as the blood supply will become too constricted. Interested in hearing from anyone who has had RT after reconstruction and the effects on the new boob. I am going to the Genesis Centre in Windsor and start in a couple of weeks so will be in the May group. Anyone been treated there?
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Thank you for your post Katiepie. I am waiting for my planning meeting after a 6 week break following 5 months of chemo. Not having tattoos as they will make a "digital map" of me (Genesis Centre in Windsor). Sure that I am going to be emotional too as very weepy at the moment! Interesting about the views on cream. Hope my radiographer feels the same as R1 and R2 are expensive. I swear by Aveeno but cold aloe vera sounds lovely. You will be 1 or 2 zaps ahead of me but that is only a matter of days. Sure it will feel good to get this bit of our treatment over quickly. We have got this! Ann xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Such a worry for you Caz. My third one was in for 8 days and I couldnt understand why it collected so much when the other 2 finished so quickly. One of those things I was told. I agree you should speak to your nurse. It will come out soon so try not to worry.
Posts.Title: mastectomy, post op day 5, one drain out the other still very liv...

Posts.Content: Best Christmas present! Good luck with the final bits of treatment. Every happiness in 2018!
Posts.Title: Today’s Results from my lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I am having EC first (last one on 28th). The meds do a brilliant job at dealing with the horrible effects so no sickness for me. I do feel washed out and nauseous for about 7 days. I had crippling heartburn first time but Omperazole keeps it bearable. I have a permanent foul taste in my mouth so live on sherbert lemons, frozen pineapple, orange ice lollies and lemon drinks. The bad days are tough for me to get through but I hang on to the fact that its temporary. Dont know how the next lot of chemo will affect me. Keep strong Ann
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Shit is a great word Mavi as are all other expletives that came out of my mouth 6 months ago!!! Social media group really works for me and a notebook that I still write in every day. I am coming up to half way through my chemo after a single mastectomy. Most of my lymph nodes were positive so they are throwing every chemical at me to kill any stray cancer cells. Side effects of chemo are horrible but bearable. I set up a file and folder for all the paperwork - hard copies and electronic. Keep breathing. Ann
Posts.Title: New to site and recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hello Ansti I had my MX nearly 7 weeks ago (with reconstruction). People have likened this experience to a roller coaster but I like roller coasters. What I cannot go on are the rides that take you from a standing start to 80 mph a in a couple of seconds and that is what it has felt like. The weeks of testing then diagnosis then surgery take your breath away. I think when medical teams decide that an MX secures your survival it is enough for a patient to process and best case scenario is that you will just need tablets afterwards. During surgery your lymph nodes will be checked and removed if cancerous. That is the unknown. My surgeon had to deliver the bad news that he had had to remove all my nodes and most of them were cancerous. I do not have breast cancer anymore but to reduce the odds of getting secondaries I am having chemo and RT.  I am sure that this is why your team are saying that it is a possibility. But it is worse case scenario and although it was horrible news I have accepted my treatment is going to last a bit longer. There is nothing that you can do to change what they will find during your MX so enjoy your pre op days and deal with the next challenge when it comes. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Surgery in 10 days, then .... no idea

Posts.Content: Morning Lizzy4U I took front fastening night shirts a size larger than normal to make access easy for the medical team. Also some cushions to protect your wounds from the seatbelt when you go home. I wasted money on drain holders when the hospital grips did the job perfectly. Anyone want a Barrista apron? Good luck xx
Posts.Title: DIEP/TRAM Surgery - what to bring to hospital?

Posts.Content: Ask for a porthacath Alison. Minor surgery with local anaesthetic. I have mine in my chest and it just shows as a small lump. Nurses magically insert needle (sharp scratch) to collect bloods and put in chemo. So much better than cannula. Ann
Posts.Title: PICC line or not?

Posts.Content: Forget the PJ bottoms - hope your BC nurse has told you about the big pants!!! :-D
Posts.Title: DIEP/TRAM Surgery - what to bring to hospital?

Posts.Content: I know how you feel Rockchick. When you first hear what the medical team need to do you just think that you are going to be ill for a year but it wont be like that. Yes it is going to be tough and some days you will not want to do anything but most of your days will be manageable. After a single mastectomy  with DIEP flap reconstruction and full clearance in August I am half way through chemo. The drugs available to deal with the nasty affects are amazing and the team will look after you. It is hard not to worry but you will be able to do it and keep working even though it will be one of the hardest things you will ever do. Good luck Ann
Posts.Title: not the news I wanted today!!

Posts.Content: Hello Optimistic So sorry that you are going through a dark time. I am suffering from PTSD following a car crash last year so getting BC has set me back big time. Your symptoms certainly sound similar to mine and I thnk that you need to see a psychotherapist. I doubt you will get a referral on NHS quickly so if you have some pennies available I think it is a good imvestment. The important thing is to talk and then talk some more. My therapist got me to write everything down in detail and then highlight all the negative thoughts. We then talked about those and came up with "scripts" of rational thinking that I can use whenever I have those thoughts. She also taught me to accept that a terrible thing has happened to me and all the bad thoughts and feelings are perfectly normal. I am not going mad!!!! I would also make the most of the times when you do not feel too bad. Have a shower, dress, put some make up on and meet friends/do something you love. I have just been to the hairdressers for a wash and blow dry. Please know that this is a temporary thing and you will get better. Keep posting.
Posts.Title: Ptsd

Posts.Content: Wow! So happy for you Lindsay.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Thank you Cords. Glad to know that I am not the only one who feels so scared prior to surgery. So lovely when you open your eyes and realise that you are still alive! So very tired with the frequency of obs but sure that they will reduce over the next few days. So pleased to hear that you are making a good recovery and great that you have managed to go out. Exhausted at the moment but I am sure that I will get to enjoy that very soon. So reassuring to message other women going through similar experiences.
Posts.Title: Big op tomorrow!

Posts.Content: So pleased for you. It is a great feeling isnt it. Take it slow getting back to fitness. I think that you still need to rest after such a long invasive treatment. Not being a party pooper just want you to be careful. I am 4 days ahead of you but sounds like you will be bouncing around long before me because I am OldandUnfit!!! :-D
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: LOL - as the young say (I think!). Little and often probably is the best rule for most things. All the best!
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Morning everyone Moving here from the May group. Off for #11 this morning and not doing too bad. Keep waiting for an horrible SE to happen but maybe I am one of the lucky ones. Lots of love and hugs to all having this treatment with an extra squeeze for those starting this month. Ann xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: I have had the same experience Fundamentals. Day after day everyone was so impressed that my skin was coping then on the penultimate treatment I had developed a red area on my chest. Since finishing that has got sore and itchy and another sore area has come out under my arm at the side of my foob. Using the cold aloe vera and Aveeno. I was also given hydrocortisone cream and some cold gel packs. I think the factor 30+ protection is the most important thing and not the brand of sun protection. All the best xx
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: How are you? I had a mastectomy and reconstruction yesterday morning and cannot believe that 24 hours after going to recovery I have just been brought to my room from ICU. It is amazing that just a day ago I thought the white ceiling would be the last thing that I would ever see. Pain being managed and I have had something to eat. Still a long way to go but the treatment has started well. Hoping you are feeling equally positive.
Posts.Title: Big op tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Off for my last zap today. Ringing that bell about midday. Luckily I just have some redness on my chest that is itchy and sore. Got some nice gel pads from the unit as well as using Aveeno and cold Aloe Vera. Today marks the end of invasive treatments so looking forward to a rest from hospital appointments. It will be weird after a year!  Just wanted to make sure that all of you at the early point in your treatments know that the end does eventual arrive and it can be done.  Take care all.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Thought you would like to see that it will be finish before you know it. One year to the day since my diagnosis.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: I did Weeblemum. Pink champagne was shared with friends.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: WOW! Now you are just showing off. Really pleased that you are feeling so well and full of energy. Long may it last.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: I have the gel slabs too - very cooling. I have also got some hydrocortisone cream to use when it gets very itchy!
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: You carry on feeling sorry for yourself Tulip! You are entitled to keep asking for advice and support. We have to put up with so much crap for which nothing can be done but the RT effects can be treated so ask away.
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ June 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hello I had my long hair cut short before starting chemo. I chose not to have the cold cap because from what I read and watched  it added time and discomfort to the sessions without much benefit. My hair started to fall out after 2 weeks. It was thick so there was a lot to come out in my hands after a shower or brushing. There was hair everywhere!!! I had my head shaved and it has been ok. I have bought some lovely slip on turbans and added bling.
Posts.Title: Loosing your hair...

Posts.Content: I got my head shaved Chloecat because I couldnt cope with my hair falling out. There was so much of it! Then wore bamboo turbans but bald around family and friends.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello Chloe Please do not think people are being negative because they chose medical intervention. All of us went through what you are feeling and in total shock about the recommended treatment. I could not believe that straight away the medical teams said I had to have my breast cut off. A second opinion at the Royal Marsden confirmed that was the only way to stay alive.Two weeks later I am tumour free and recovering from my surgery. That is what I am fighting for - to stay alive and go back to enjoying my wonderful life. This is a disease and maybe other therapies can help you cope with your illness but they cannot cure you. I wish you well in deciding what is the right way for you to go
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: WOW! Thank you so much for letting us know about this. Being the advance team going ahead is so brave of you. It is because of people like you Chloecat, cancer treatment is able to move forward. The Sono bit appears to be new in the UK so you have added another light at the end of the tunnel. Thank you.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: I had to play around with the laxative dose to get comfortable bowel movements. Preferred diarroeha to constipation though!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: How scary for you Chloecat! Never had anything that bad but each of us react differently to having our body flooded with poison. I definitely was very weak and tired during the 10 days after each infusion. Resting and sleeping is the only option I think. I also had a bottle by my bed so I didnt have to go to the bathroom at night. No dignity with cancer. Look after yourself and keep going - it will end xx
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Have you got a Medical Alert card with your chemo info Chloecat? Just flash that at A&E and fast track. Saves having to do all the talking and repeating yourself.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Thank you Judith x
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Glad you have got through the worse days of your first cycle. I found it mentally challenging going back each time knowing I would go from feeling ok to feeling crap. I would be cautious about not taking anti-sickness tablets until you start vomiting as that is a horrible thing to go through on top of everything else. Maybe reduce the dose next time and see how you feel? Enjoy next week.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Had a real shock today - 18 months after my diagnosis my sister phoned me to tell me that she has breast cancer. What is going on? There is no history of this rubbish disease in the family. Our poor brothers and dad are going to be devastated again. She has an 18 year old daughter and as you all know my sister is dreading telling her. I will support her all I can and she wants me to go to her next hospital appointment for the MRI results and final discussions about her op booked for 27th.  I want be a good sister but I am dreading going through it with her.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Good old M&S worked for me. It is 2 months since the op and I still wear them as they are more comfortable than other pants. My big problem was getting a bra that fitted. Had a real meltdown in the hospital. Ended up with a sport bra that was best fit from JD Williams as couldnt get big enough cup size from M&S. Stay well.
Posts.Title: Underwear woes after diep flap

Posts.Content: Your description of the pain seems to suggest nerve pain. Talk to your doctor. I take pregabalin which helps me. Hateful to be in pain.
Posts.Title: Painkillers, alternatives when the standard ones don't work after...

Posts.Content: Hello Wendy I had reconstruction at the same time as mx nearly 3 weeks ago. I had a DIEP flap so no muscle taken and from what I have read that adds a bit more pain. It is painful when the aneasthetic eventual wears off. I found the tummy wound the most painful and you cannot stand upright for a couple of days. But it is bearable pain and you should take all the pain relief on offer! I was home after a week and my wounds are healing well. As with any op it is all about resting and sleeping. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction and reduction

Posts.Content: Hello Sally20 Everyone responds differently to the surgery but it helped me to read other people's stories. I had the same op 6 weeks ago. The tummy wound was the most painful and it was a few days before I could stand up straight. I had a catheter in for 4 days which saved a lot of hassle.  Because of the amazing way that the surgeons work from inside my body, my abdomen felt very strange - like a hot water bottle! I had lots of nodes removed so under my arm was very sore as sensation returned - like really bad sunburn. I was in hospital for a week and the car journey home was tough, especially over bumps. Within 4 weeks my wounds were healed and I started applying bio oil. I was able to drive after 5 weeks and I am now home alone. My armpit is still numb and the sensation is slowly returning under my arm. My foob is swollen and sore. I will start chemo in a few weeks followed by radiotherapy. After that I will have surgery reduction of my other breast. I am off to get my hair cut short on Thursday. I am not going to bother with the cold cap or have a fake nipple. Good luck with your surgery and the follow up scans. I plan to post my chemo story and hope you will have good news for us after your surgery.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction and reduction

Posts.Content: Hard to answer as I do not know what an implant would have been like. Definitely didnt want to go flat. I think using your own body has got to be better than putting something man-made in. I am old enough not to worry about what my body looks like in terms of intimacy but I have been assured that when the swelling goes down that it will be hard for others to tell the difference (apart from no nipple in my case). 3 months on and the tummy scar which is on the bikini line is all healed and over time will fade. I am still numb in my armpit (but I had all my lymph nodes removed) and there is a small scar from where my nipple was to under my arm. Knowing how it was I would still make the same choice. It is so hard to make these decidions when you are reeling from the diagnosis!  Hope it goes as well as possible for you.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and immediate reconstruction by diep at St Thomas' hospital...

Posts.Content: Hello moresleep I had mastectomy with DIEP flap reconstruction on Aug 22nd at Royal Marsden. It is a big operation and the tummy wound is significant from hip to hip.I was in hospital for a week and the first two days were rough particularly as sleep is interrupted through the frequent obs that have to be done. It was about 4 weeks before I could stretch and stand up straight. I was driving again after 6 weeks. The new breast is very realistic and feels natural - though at 61 I will have to have further surgery on my right breast to gain symmetry. I lost ny nipple and I have decided to get a full size tattoo done when I have finished my treatment. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Mastectomy and immediate reconstruction by diep at St Thomas' hospital...

Posts.Content: Foul tasting mouth is the thing that I have all the time so I rely on sherbert lemons, frozen pineapple chunks and orange ice lollies. Definitely rest for the first few days after chemo - just settle in with good books and box sets and sleep whenever you can. Merry Christmas Ann
Posts.Title: Advice /help needed

Posts.Content: I have got into strawberry milk Peanut11. Just tried everything until I liked something. Also manage tea with just a splash of milk and a teaspoon of sugar (which I havent used since I was a child!) I have found that I crave much sweeter things in my mouth since starting chemo. Agree with everyone on the orange ice lollies - great when you cannot face a drink. Good luck finding the best for you.
Posts.Title: Drink

Posts.Content: This poem was on a Facebook group. I found it really helpful as I can never find the words to explain how I feel. It's a bit long so hope the system can cope! They said to go home. They said the scans look fine, your body will recover, you don’t need to be here anymore. They said to go home. They said, “we don’t know if it will come back, but it very well might. Until then there’s not much we can do.” They said, “go on and live your life.” Take a breath, take a nap, maybe even take a vacation. Go back to your jobs, back to your hobbies, back to laundry, dishes, and paying the bills. Spend time with your family, meet a friend for lunch, catch a movie with your loved ones. Take a day to do absolutely nothing. It sounded nice when they said to go home. So we went home. But the home we went back to wasn’t as familiar as we thought. The paint was the same color and the furniture was in place, but it didn’t feel like the same home. Our thoughts, feelings, and interests had all changed. Our relationships, jobs, and bodies felt so much different. They said to go home, so we tried to go home, but it didn’t feel like home. We felt lost. It was as if we had been on a path, kidnapped somewhere in the middle, turned around 20 times, and set off in a new direction. We didn’t know which way was up or down, left or right. We were in a new place, stranded in the desert- abandoned, desolate and lonely. They said to go home. But home was out of reach. The home we knew didn’t exist anymore. We wandered around for awhile before trying to build a new home. But the new home crumbled and cracked, forcing us to repair, rebuild, or start completely over. They said to go home. But they didn’t understand. After seeing thousands of patients in this position, they still didn’t understand. It looked so simple from their perspective. Go home, go back to your life, pretend that cancer never came. But we couldn’t go home. Our souls were altered on the deepest level. Our hearts were shattered, our minds were chaos, and our bodies hurt. They couldn’t see it. But then we saw others. “Do you know where you are going?” we asked. “No, I feel rather lost,” they would say. “But you are welcome to join, and we can pave a new path together.” In that moment, though we were all still lost, we felt a glimpse of home. Our hearts connected and friendships formed on the simplest notion of being aimless wanderers together. “Your thoughts and feelings make sense given all that you’ve been through. Others may not understand, but I can see, because I’ve walked a similar path.” “You belong here.” Our hearts began to relax. We took a deep breath of fresh air. They said to come home.

Posts.Content: Good one Ali xx
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: It does indeed Lesley. Glad you appreciated it as much as me xx

Posts.Content: Morning all

Posts.Content: I like this one. Hope everyone is ok.

Posts.Content: Wouldn't this be wonderful!???

Posts.Content: Liked this one Hope there are many days in 2019 when everyone can do something that brings them joy.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Saw this one and thought of us.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: My sister also thinks a positive perspective on everything is helpful. So at 62 I am "lucky to get a tummy tuck and boob job for free". I know she means well but all I have ever wanted is for her to put her arms around me and let me know that she understands how crappy everything is. Unlike you WhatHappened, it is my sister-in-law who has done that. Hey Ho :-D
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Love this one Violetsniff.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Have a good weekend everyone.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Saw this one today and it really helped me this morning.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Saw this on a coffee shop wall. Good old Mark Twain. Hope you are having a good day.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: One of those nights! Listening to Simon Mayo and Mark Kermode podcast. I will probably be contentidly asleep at 9am when I have to be awake!
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Rant away ali owl! Those not in the cancer club have no understanding of what it is like to live with this crappy disease. Great business idea. Good luck xx
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Reminds me of this poem:
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hope you are feeling a little better #ali owl.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: One of those nights! Listening to Simon Mayo and Mark Kermode podcast. I will probably be contentidly asleep at 9am when I have to be awake!
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Love your post Violetsniff. I was so glad that those I loved didn't have to endure the pain. Unfairly my sister was diagnosed with breast cancer 18 months after me. It has brought us closer and she has apologised for the "positive" comments she made about my surgery benefits but hate to see her go through the pain.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Got this one from my local support group.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: A poem by Nancy's Point blog celebrating National Poetry month. I miss them – Their shape, their naturalness and how they made me feel. Anatomy parts that once were mine, and then one day just gone. I never said a proper goodbye. There wasn’t time. There was the cancer… I have new ones now, quite different from my firsts. Their shape, their feel is still quite foreign, as if they don’t belong. Because of course, they don’t. I miss them. Sometimes it seems I should not say this, Or even dare to think it. I am alive. I should be grateful. And I am, but… I miss them. I didn’t want to part with them and pretend it didn’t matter. It did. It does. It always will. I know now that grief and gratitude can co-exist. And so I’m done pretending. I miss them. It’s okay to feel this way and say so right out loud. And so I’m done pretending. I miss them.
Posts.Title: Thought for the Day..

Posts.Content: Hello Edwina I drew my eyebrows in with a pencil. I wear false eyelashes. All new to me in my 62 years! The good news is that it will all come back before you know it. After 2 months from end of 8 lots of chemo my eyebrows are back (having them waxed on Thursday) and my eyelashes are on their way. I will be able to have extensions soon. Rocking very short silver grey hair too! All the best in your treatment and recovery. This too will pass.
Posts.Title: Eyebrows and eyelashes - What do you do when they are gone??

Posts.Content: Oh my gosh nictaff - so sorry that you have ended up in hospital. I only had one crisis during chemo. Got two nasty burns from RT but they are healing. I think I am still operating in a bubble even after year. I just go where I am told take what they say. I think I am too scared to think about everything in detail or I might explode and be an emotional wreck! I live in Reading and I am going to listen to a woman called Vicky Martin. Her talk is called unstoppable. Need something to snap me out of this stupor. I feel like I need someone to scream at me "YOU HAVE CANCER!" Hope we both feel better soon!
Posts.Title: Anastrozole & Turmeric/Curcumin

Posts.Content: Hey Coastal-Lady. I am also suffering joint pains from Anastrazole. Already taking pain killers for consequences of a car crash 2 years ago so very interested in alternatives to manage joint pain. Hope someone in the community can help.
Posts.Title: Anastrozole & Turmeric/Curcumin

Posts.Content: Will ask Onco about that dalefarm. Thank you
Posts.Title: Anastrozole & Turmeric/Curcumin
